<@U02QXF15X27> Tracey Zabar is interested in an old, falling-apart cookbook in Italian. She's more interested in its appearance (old) than in its subject matter. This will be disassembled for an art project.

replies.text: Do we have a sense of how old? Does she want leather binding and yellowed pages, or something that might have really dated photographs, or something else?
Binding is unimportant. She wants text pages, and she's envisioning yellowed pages; I think high acid pages would be fine since she mentioned crumbling once or twice. No mention of images.
Heard! I'll see what I can do? Any timeline?
I told her we could give an idea on Wednesday if we had anything at all. But she's not expecting us to produce something immediately.

replies.text: Unfortunately, we don't have an account with this publisher and I don't see enough demand for French-language copies to make it possible to open an account and order a case of books.  So we'd have to pay full retail for the book, which would mean charging Nancy a significant premium over its list price. I've emailed Appetite for Books to see if they stock it.
Nancy seemed to think the author was doing an English translation, as well, but that is clearly further down the road.
She has another book coming from Simon in the Spring, but it's a book about the food of Montreal, so that does not seem to be this book.
No, Nancy said this book in particular she thought the author was translating herself for some future release.
